title: Businessman Brian Smart jailed for seven years for sexual abuse of young boys
text:
Mugshot: Brian Smart, 69, jailed for seven years

A leading British businessman was jailed for seven years for sexually abusing young boys at his home after his 'urges got out of control' following the death of his wife.

Brian Smart, 69, was the Director General of the British Franchise Association for 27 years working alongside government adviser Sir Bernard Ingham.

A court heard Smart kept his interest in boys a secret throughout his marriage but lost control of his urges when his wife died.

The 69-year-old invited a 15-year-old boy into his home and let him run up a £700 bill on an Xbox gaming console.

He also set up a two-way mirror to spy on a 'vulnerable boy' he had staying at his £500,000 home in Wales, the jury was told.

Smart admitted charges of sexual assault, inciting a child under 13 to engage in a sexual act and possession of indecent photographs of children.

He was given an indefinite Sexual Harm Prevention order and an indefinite Restraining Order preventing him from having any contact with the boys.

Recorder of Merthyr Tydfil, Judge Richard Twomlow, said he was satisfied Smart is not a dangerous offender.

Smart, 69, was the Director General of the British Franchise Association for 27 years working alongside government adviser Sir Bernard Ingham

He told him: 'It is clear that the death of your wife was a traumatic experience for you but it cannot justify your behaviour.

'You were in a position of trust which you abused. The offences are so serious only a prison sentence can be justified.'

Prosecutor Robin Rouch said: 'The boy was scared after Smart kissed him in the bathroom at his home.

'Smart expected the boy to pay off £700 he ran up on the Xbox by allowing him to repeat what had happened.'

When the second boy's mother found the mirror, Smart said he was lonely and it was his way of having intimate contact with people.

She called police who seized recording equipment and computers from Smart's property. The court heard he gave officers passwords to examine their contents.

After hearing of Smart's arrest, a woman became concerned because her 12-year-old son had stayed with him for four nights in December 2017.

Mr Rees said: 'The boy was in bed early one morning when his mother asked him if Mr Smart had ever touched him. The boy pulled the duvet over his head and said: 'Yes'.'

Merthyr Tydfil Crown Court heard Smart carried out more serious sexual assaults on the younger boy including one which the judge described as the 'headline offence'.

Jonathan Rees, defending, said: 'He is horrified, hugely ashamed and hopes both boys can recover from the trauma he has caused them.

'He accepts the offences are sexual and the motivation was to seek intimacy with the two boys. He had betrayed their trust and that of their parents.'

Smart admitted charges of sexual assault, inciting a child under 13 to engage in a sexual act and possession of indecent photographs of children.

The court heard the offences were out of character and committed at a time when he was 'distressed' at the loss of his wife Sian from a brain tumour.

Smart had left his London home and relocated to the picture postcard village of Talybont-on-Usk, in the Brecon Beacons National Park.

Father-of-one Smart has referred himself to a psychiatrist to 'address his issues' and has been receiving treatment for 18 months.

Mr Rees said: 'These offences occurred during an isolated and distressing period for Mr Smart. They do not form any wider pattern of offending.'

Smart, in gold-rimmed spectacles, grey suit and dark blue tie showed no emotion as the details of his sordid offences against both boys were read to the court.

He retired from the British Franchise Association three years ago but the organisation still gives an award for international development in his name each year.

The 69-year-old worked alongside Margaret Thatcher's press secretary Sir Bernard Ingham who was president of the organisation for 18 years up until 2012.

The British Franchise Association describes itself as the voice of ethical franchising in the UK and works closely with industry and the Government.

The association declined to comment on Smart's conviction.
description: Brian Smart, 69, worked at the British Franchise Association alongside ex-government adviser Sir Bernard Ingham. Smart  committed the offences at his home in Talybont-on-Usk in Wales.
